column1: Biomaterials can take on many different forms and be made from many different materials. Ideally
column2: biomaterials should have a porous structure
column3: which means they have small holes which lets gasses
column5: and even cells move through them
column6: similar to the organ or tissue they aim to heal. Cells that help in healing can also be loaded into the small pores in the biomaterial. In this way
column7: a porous biomaterial can be used to deliver cells to a damaged tissue. The biomaterial helps keep the new cells in the tissue where they are needed to promote healing. Additionally
column8: the porous structure of the biomaterial is a lot like the "extracellular matrix
column9: which is like the scaffolding that cells hold on to" in the body. Biomaterials can either be used by themselves as a treatment
column12: they can be modified to contain medicine or cells to help repair damaged tissues.
